[LEXICON]: "drawn on" (slightly archaic phrasing, but contextually acceptable)
[SYNTAX]: "no little to the discomfort" (archaic construction, but not disruptive)

[STRUCTURE]: Sudden shift from personal experience (rainy season discomfort) to historical exposition (Manila’s founding) without clear transition.
[LOGIC]: Minor disconnect between the bridge scene’s cosmopolitan description and the abrupt transition to the notice about teachers.
[TRANSITION]: Jarring jump from the troop embarkation scene to the native woman’s actions without narrative linkage.

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect semicolon usage in "The work of the teachers was, in short; to 'make...'"
[REDUNDANCY]: Repetition in "so varied and so different from one another"
[PUNCTUATION]: Missing period after "thus" in "Thus it can be easily seen..."
[LEXICON]: Ambiguous phrasing in "in the native language" (unclear which language is meant)

[STRUCTURE]: Sudden shift from teachers' work to the "baile" chapter without transitional context
[CLARITY]: Jarring presentation of the "official report" as a direct quote without framing

[LEXICON]: "slyly stealing up our nostrils to send us nerve dispatches" is overly verbose and awkward.
[SYNTAX]: "the first and also the last number of every Filipino dance" is redundant phrasing.
"the question of regulating servants is one of no small importance" is wordy.
"the last course was dulce" lacks article before noun.
[SPELLING]: "dulce" is correctly used but could be italicized/quoted for clarity.
"new-comers" hyphenation is outdated (modern usage would be "newcomers").

[STRUCTURE]: Sudden shift from dance descriptions to house-keeping section lacks transitional phrase.
[LOGIC]: Mention of "St. Vitus" appears without prior context establishment.
[TRANSITION]: Jump from dinner/dance observations to commercial sourcing of goods feels abrupt.
[CLARITY]: "the whole Filipino race attached to our culinary force" is hyperbolic but maintains narrative flow.

[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing in "it must be paid for at the price it commands"
[PUNCTUATION]: Missing comma before "unless" in "unless you object to the frequent clouds of dust"
